content.body: Hello
anyone here work with the python version of html5lib?? I'm working on debugging an error with processSpaceCharacters and would appreciate any advice
amites1, jgraham and annevk do, but they're not here at this time of night.
amites1, gsnedders|work or Philip` too may be able to help though
doesn't seem like any of them are on right now
I appreciate your looking out
amites1, they'll most likely be here within about 5 or 6 hours when they wake up
*Grin* if I don't have it figured out by then
changed servers and upgraded a couple things, everything but PDF generation went smooth
giggles a bit at the WAI procedure thread
does python have the equivalent of the C-like ?: operator?
Hixie: http://marc-abramowitz.com/archives/2008/05/18/python-ternary-operator/
thanks!
I can't see what exactly in the proposed procedure that we're not doing, beyond the fact that we haven't yet reached a mutually agreeable solution
and that won't happen as long as the WAI PFWG continues to do nothing but push for one specific solution, without accepting or working with any alternatives
Lachy: I'm probably not a good person to speak to about html5lib for future reference
I can't stand everyone in public_html being politely dishonest to one another
i'm trying to be politely honest
Hixie: sometimes it's not possible to be both polite and honest at the same time
and you need to make a choice
i usually shut up in those cases
me too
roc: I'm considering being honestly impolite
but it seems like it would be a waste of time and energy in this case
othermaciej: I recommend you going with your instincts there.
MikeSmith: sometimes being honestly impolite is useful
it doesn't work too well online unfortunately
othermaciej, if you were to be honestly impolite on the mailing list, what would you say?
or rather, what point would you want to make?
Lachy, given the people who love to read our logs and send creepy emails about them, that would amount to a cowardly way to post to the list
You could say it in our secret IRC channel instead
--> #whatwg-cabal
Philip`: how do you know I haven't?
shh, don't tell anyone!
if you guys do set up a secret cabal list could you please log it so that i can find your discussions when i do google searches for relevant discussion?
can't you use Google's abusive monopolistic control of the internet to just log all the traffic anyway?
We could set up the list on Google Wave, so Hixie can use the secret wiretap backdoor to track and analyse the discussions
we need a way to allow robots to index the content, but to keep it secret, a way to block unwanted humans from heading it.
and we don't yet have a Human Exclusions Protocol (humans.txt)
i'm going to go to bed before your conspiracy theories get me in trouble
nn :-)
Lachy: you need to run with that Human Exclusion Protocol idea. do an IETF Internet draft
MikeSmith, I was just thinking about an April Fools RFC for that :-)
Would it apply if Koko the Gorilla starts using a Web browser?
heh
Human-Agent: Mike*
Disallow: /
MikeSmith: Quick, change to billyjackass!
hmm, reading some blog posts for the past few weeks it seems like a remarkable number of people really had faith in XHMTML2
is it going to be possible for javascript to render other formats like PDF in html5?
mookid: I guess the main issue with that is lack of a binary data type
hmm
ok
frustrating because the only option right now is to popup a new window
mookid: Otherwise, I don't think there's anything stopping you (from converting to either HTML/SVG elements, or rendering onto a canvas)
eww that's pretty gnarly
mookid: Not just use object or something?
mookid: Well, how else would you render it with Javascript?
mookid: Am I missing what you meant?
situation I'm in - if I make XMLHttpRequest to a pdf document
how do I get that rendered?
Convert it to a data URI and set an object's data to it?
Why not just set the object's data to the URL you request with XHR?
cos it's got custom headers :P
I was guessing that
there is one way that I guess would work - which is to render a flash app and pass the data into that
If it contains any null bytes, be warned that Opera at least truncates responseText at that
Converting it to a data URI should work, though
yeah XMLHttpRequest is pretty bad
are there any plans to update/fix that?
can we at least drop the XML infront of it?
The null issue? I guess the answer is I can't comment on that.
We can't really drop the XML in the name because thousands of sites rely upon it being there
Http is equally misleading, as you can make FTP requests too in theory
(or any other scheme)
can't you just change it and make the old name a pointer?
Yes, but is it worthwhile changing that?
well I think it can be improved anyway
the spec could be more vigorous wrt the HTTP spec
We're gonna have to keep backwards compat with XHR forever, more or less, so adding an alias doesn't help.
Vigorous in what way?
3xx forwards are very bad right now in XHR
+ the object could be structured in a more intuitive fashion
http://cloudofdata.com/2009/07/does-linked-data-need-rdf/
nah it doesnt
:P
mookid: That can't really be changed for backwards compat. reasons
gsnedders|work: ok so is there room to create a new client library?
mookid: I doubt it'll be added at a browser level (on grounds that XHR already exists)
mookid: What's your issue with redirects?
well they're inconsistent and the object makes it very hard to get a handle on what's actually going on
the implementations are inconsistent
That's an implementation issue, and all are moving towards the current WD
Actually, I expect the current ED
maybe I'm not up enough on XHR but redirects follows are automated for some 3xx codes right?
For "HTTP redirects"
scariest idea ever
give your javascript sandbox namespaces a URI
then I can give an object a data URI
so essentially what you're saying is I can't use XHR response data to render a PDF?
huh?
nvm =)
having an accept header attribute would make my life a lot easier.. ;D
Take the responseText, encode as base64, then add before that data:application/pdf;base64,
How does that not work?
what do you do with that from there though?
I can't render it or make it available to save to disk in a browser sandbox
var obj = document.createElement("object"); obj.data = foobar;
Then add the obj and if there is a PDF plugin installed, it'll render.
*add the obj to the tree somewhere
oh right hmm lol
I'm sure I read somewhere you can't do that
is that new?
No, but I'm pretty certain that should work
If it doesn't, you've hit browser bugs
sound, cheers
There may be some other way that I haven't thought off, though.
Do PDFs contain null bytes often?
haven't looked into that yet
As I say, any containing null bytes will fail in Opera
ok bear with me here - if the browser has no plugin installed - there's no way to provide a save to disk dialogue box?
MikeSmith: was that link for me?
mookid: What the browser does in that case is implementation dependant behaviour.
mookid: But there's no way to force a browser to provide a save dialogue without running in a privileged state
mookid: what link?
the RDF one
RDF vs. LinkedData
nope
k
that was for all us, for our collective edification
sweet
mookid: you have an interest in linked data?
Hmmm - I'd like to say yes
but honestly I'm not realy qualified to say that
I know REST and I'm working on a layered platform
but I'm not using RDF
so that article sounds good to me
granted.. RDF seems like a pretty nice tool for 'fractal' data graphs
it's just more cost to my project right now
I'm all set up to introduce an additional RDF layer whenever I need :)
thanks to URI's and content negotiation
sometimes it costs more to add stuff later
I don't actually know much about RDF beyond the very basics
still isn't sure using URIs to identify things is entirely sensible
I mean, what URI do I use for my grandmother?
there's a joke there somwhere
btw, a note while I'm thinking about it: If somebody ever does do XML5, it should relax the restriction that comments can't contain "--"
still thinks XML5 should be a strict subset of XML 1.0 4th edition
along with all other "backwards compatible with SGML" constraints
gsnedders|work: it's all to do with how you actually define a Resource
is reminded that he meant to open a bug about the phrase "backwards compatible" in the spec intro
MikeSmith: if I wanted to introduce RDF to my system I'd only have to add another layer of RDF representations ontop of my existing URIs
and I can do that easily with Accept/Content-Type headers
gsnedders|work: What do you mean by "strict subset"? (All well-formed XML1 documents must parse to the same DOM when using the XML5 algorithm? That sounds more like a superset to me)
can a Resource just be a particular stream of data transmitted over TCP/IP?
Philip`: I mean in terms of document conformance.
Philip`: But yes, the parsing should be a superset, and conforming a subset
gsnedders|work: So all conforming XML5 documents should also be conforming XML1 documents, but not the other way around?
Philip`: Yeah.
Philip`: Because DOCTYPE is evil.
gsnedders|work: Okay, makes sense
gsnedders|work: why do you say that?
I suppose my main complaint with XML is not that draconian error handling is bad, but that it's too complex to follow the rules in practice
MikeSmith: technically, yes - if you were logging TCP/IP traffic you could give each packet a URI
but the actual data trasmitted is a representation
e.g. properly-nested tags and quoted attributes are pretty easy, and the pain is in the complex character requirements and the forbidden sequences like "]]>" and "--"
(and in doctypes)
could you use JSON?
notes XHTML, Atom, and RSS are not JSON, so for most people using XML the answer is no.\
I mean use JSON for HTML5
If you define a JSON serialization of a DOM, sure.
well isn't it better suited than XML?~
I thought there's an issue with XML in terms of what you can actually assume about the data from the order/tag heirarchy
there must be most of that work already done within apps like firebug..?
Someone should modify something like http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/misc/sexp.html to work with JSON
Kris Zyp is/was working on JSON-Schema and json references
where schema's all linked together and could reference one another /themselves
I dunno exctly how fruity the DOM is but I would imagine you can break it down quite neatly
Anyone from Mozilla around?
Or anyone with a clue of how to report a bug in Gecko?
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=broken-website.html says to go through the Help menu, but I don't have a "Report Broken Web Site" in the nightly I have.
gsnedders|work: Just use Bugzilla normally, and file a bug with a test case?
Philip`: You aren't allowed to do that nowadays.
Oh well, their problem.
Uh, not allowed to file bugs?
"IMPORTANT: if the problem is with a broken web page, you need to report it a different way."
So seeming you're not.
That sounds like it's meant for bug reports like "I visited Yahoo Mail and it doesn't work"
grumbles
and I'd hope you have more detail and a minimised test case and then you could file a proper bug :-)
I'm reporting one of their tests is broken (and so is their behaviour that passes it)
gsnedders|work: Then just fill out the bug form and put all the relevant details in it
finds through one really obscure bit of the spec that the tests are right, and he is wrong.
why doesn't the spec allow multi-letter accesskey values?
I'm having a surprisingly difficult time finding XHTML 1.0 and HTML 5 test suites.
what would an XHTML1 test suite test?
HTML 3.2, obviously
I mean, I wasn't aware there were many testable things in XHTML1
takkaria: I assume it normatively includes HTML4, so you could test all of HTML4's conformance requirements
I was just trying to find thoser but it looks like w3.org is having problems
takkaria: Browser conformance.

There seems to be no good statistics on how well browsers support XHTML 1.0, and as that is the last standard to support text/html, and IE doesn't support application/xhtml+xml, and it was released 9 years ago, I think that it qualifies as the most important current standard.  And I think there should be better browser support statistics on current standards.
XHTML is predominantly treated as HTML 4.0-serialized-as-XML
(from my experience)
jcranmer: So you would expect browser conformance to be the same between HTML4 and XHTML 1.0?
Darxus, XHTML as text/html is, as far as the browser is concerned, simply HTML.
Lachy: Thank you.
